Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Paintable Solar Reflective Coatings for Cool Roof Retrofits
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will bring a new family of "structural color" coatings to the commercial marketplace as an alternative to toxic pigments and dyes, as well as a new paradigm for controlling the flow of light. This project aims to improve the energy efficiency of buildings through a coating that can be applied to residential roofing materials during installation or at the original equipment manufacturer level. The technology is a bottoms-up approach to the formation of reflective materials offering significant advantages over state-of-practice cool-roofing alternatives by retrofitting without changing the facade's appearance. The resulting product will rapidly increase adoption of cool-roof technologies due to improved performance without aesthetic loss, a key homeowner concern, leading to substantial energy savings.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses key risks and technical challenges associated with commercializing brush block copolymer based photonic crystals. This forms an ideal advanced materials platform for large-area dielectric mirrors due to the low costs of the raw materials and the simplicity of "bottoms-up" fabrication by macromolecular self-assembly. To realize commercial applications, the chemistries for these reflective organic materials need to be optimized for exterior coating applications to resist degradation from natural weathering conditions such as ultraviolet radiation, rain, thermal cycling; furthermore, the formulation must be optimized for standard application. This proposed activity will develop new synthetic routes, stabilization strategies, and the first manufacturing processes to demonstrate these unique advanced materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I award the team at Cypris Materials, Inc. addressed key risks and technical challenges associated with commercializing a disruptive coating technology. The team at Cypris previously identified an ideal organic polymer-based strategy to fabricate large-area reflective surfaces (called photonic crystals or structural color) due to low costs of the raw materials and the simplicity of the bottom-up fabrication by self-assembly. In this award, new chemistries were explored that eventually lead to improvements upon the paintable structural color platform that demonstrated improved resistance to degradation from UV exposure, humidity, thermal cycling, and was formulated into a paint/ink that could be applied via robust application methods. The continued success and improvements offer significant advantages to traditional coloration technology including sustainability, broadened color gamut, no manufacturing hassle, and simplified formulation all without the need for (toxic) pigments, dyes, metals, or expensive engineering practices.

The broader impacts of this work focused on improvements to color, the underlying unifier of almost every consumer product. The appearance of consumer goods and the instinctive reactions that color provides are crucial elements explaining why consumers choose one product over another. However, the methods of achieving color today, through pigments and dyes, comes with significant negative impacts to human health and our environment. As an example, the pigments that make green-colored plastics and paper are nearly impossible to recycle or compost because they contaminate everything else that they are recycled with. Cypris Materials, Inc. is developing the next generation of color: a nature inspired printable structural color solution that seeks to empower brands with differentiated aesthetics, improved sustainability, an augmented color gamut, and improvements to the formulation and manufacturing processes without the use of pigments or dyes. Cypris' core technology is a drop-in polymer binder that can replace or co-exist with commercial ink binders. The patented binder is designed from the same building blocks that make up the ubiquitous FDA-certified polymers found in food packaging, ensuring that the solution is not creating new untested, unintentional, or undesirable byproducts. At maturity, the success of this technology will impact the $70B colorant industry by serving as the first modular easy-to-apply structural color platform, presenting a transformative technology to markets spanning first industrial inkjet serviced markets such as consumer electronics, security, packaging, and eventually, other industries that use color such as cosmetic, automotive, and architectural.
